Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support because it is based on a four-year-old internet meme and there is no current evidence or data provided to back it up.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Hobby Lobby does not sell Jewish holiday items based on the meme, without considering any other factors or possibilities.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider the alternative explanation that Hobby Lobby may have previously carried merchandise related to Jewish holidays and is willing to re-evaluate its holiday items based on customer demand.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Hobby Lobby issued a personal apology from their president, Steve Green, and stated that they do not tolerate discrimination at their company or stores.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the issue by stating that Hobby Lobby does not sell Jewish holiday items at any of their stores, without considering the possibility of future changes or the fact that some Northeast locations started stocking Jewish holiday items on a trial basis.
Understate: The claim may understate the efforts made by Hobby Lobby to address the issue and their commitment to not discriminate, as stated in their apology and communication with the Anti-Defamation League.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not considering the statements and actions taken by Hobby Lobby to address the issue and ensure it does not happen again.
